perturbation.original_text: 8.2.1 one Party is in breach of its obligations hereunder and fails to cure such breach within ten (10) Business Days following the other  Party's written notice thereof, then the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement;
perturbation.changed_text: 8.2.1 one Party is in breach of its obligations hereunder and fails to cure such breach within two (2) Business Days following the other Party's written notice thereof, then the non-breaching Party may terminate this Agreement;
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows for a 10-day cure period after notice of breach. Reducing this cure period to 2 business days creates a contradiction, as PRC law (which governs this agreement per section 11.1) typically provides for reasonable cure periods which are often longer than 2 days, especially considering the complexity of potential breaches. This unreasonably short period may be deemed unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Contract Law - General principles of fairness and reasonableness in contract terms.

perturbation.original_text: 11.2 Any dispute, conflict or claim arising out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance hereof shall be resolved by the Parties  through amicable negotiation, which negotiation shall commence immediately upon notice by one Party to the other of the nature of  such dispute, conflict or claim. In the event that such dispute is not resolved within thirty (30) Business Days following such notice,  either Party may upon the expiration of the such 30-day notice period submit such dispute to arbitration by the Hong Kong International  Arbitration Centre in accordance with the arbitration rules of such centre then in effect.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.2 Any dispute, conflict or claim arising out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance hereof shall be resolved by the Parties  through amicable negotiation, which negotiation shall commence immediately upon notice by one Party to the other of the nature of  such dispute, conflict or claim. In the event that such dispute is not resolved within five (5) Business Days following such notice,  either Party may upon the expiration of such 5-day notice period submit such dispute to arbitration by the Hong Kong International Arbitration Centre in accordance with the arbitration rules of such centre then in effect.
perturbation.explanation: The original text stipulates a 30-day negotiation period before arbitration. Reducing this to 5 business days introduces a legal contradiction. PRC law, while allowing for arbitration, generally expects a reasonable period for good-faith negotiation before resorting to arbitration. A 5-day period is arguably too short to allow for meaningful negotiation, potentially violating principles of good faith and fair dealing which are implied into contracts under PRC law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Contract Law - Principles of good faith and fair dealing; Arbitration Law of the PRC - Requirement for a genuine attempt at negotiation.

perturbation.original_text:
ARTICLE TEN FORCE MAJEURE

In the event that a Party's performance of this Agreement or any covenants of the Parties is directly affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood,  fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, hacker attack on the Internet, amendment to law or policy or any other event of  force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party shall immediately give the other Party a  notice by fax of such event and within thirty days (30) thereafter provide a detailed report thereof as well as a certification document explaining the  cause for the non-performance or delayed performance of this Agreement, which certification document shall be issued by the public notary of the  region in which the event of force majeure occurred.
perturbation.changed_text:
ARTICLE TEN FORCE MAJEURE

In the event that a Party's performance of this Agreement or any covenants of the Parties is directly affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood,  fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, hacker attack on the Internet, amendment to law or policy or any other event of  force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party shall immediately give the other Party a  notice by fax of such event and within five days (5) thereafter provide a detailed report thereof as well as a certification document explaining the  cause for the non-performance or delayed performance of this Agreement, which certification document shall be issued by the public notary of the  region in which the event of force majeure occurred.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a 30-day period to provide a detailed report and certification for a force majeure event. Reducing this to 5 days creates a potential conflict with PRC law. Obtaining official certification from a public notary within 5 days for a force majeure event (which could involve significant disruptions) is often impractical, especially considering potential bureaucratic delays. This could be considered an unreasonable burden on the affected party, potentially making the clause unenforceable under PRC law principles of fairness and reasonableness.
perturbation.contradicted_law: PRC Contract Law - Principles of fairness and reasonableness in contract terms; General Principles of Civil Law of the PRC - Requirement for reasonableness in contractual obligations.
